image.altText: A woman with dark hair and earrings looks at the camera with a neutral expression

items.synopsis: Six months on from when Angie Fuller disappeared from the side of an outback highway, and a homicide investigation was launched, police are considering offering a reward for information.

title.children: Angie Fuller disappeared from Alice Springs six months ago. What do we know?

image.altText: The sign outside Darwin Local Court. Picture taken June 22, 2021.

items.synopsis: A Darwin woman has pleaded guilty to high range drink driving and careless driving after colliding into a traffic sign on Boxing Day last year.

title.children: Judge berates driver who blacked out and drove five times over the alcohol limit

image.altText: Four men start paddling on a boat made of cans in water at the beach

items.synopsis: More than a dozen teams participated in the NT's wildest race, diligently gathering, gluing and sealing beer cans, plastic containers, drums and other discarded materials together.

title.children: Techno Vikings triumph over US Marines in beer can boat race

image.altText: A white man with no hair, dressed in a suit, sits behind a microphone with a concerned expression.

items.synopsis: The executives of one of Australia's leading consultancy firms are criticised for their unwillingness to share information and how they handle complaints of misconduct.

title.children: Deloitte CEO admits he should not be paid seven times more than PM during Senate grilling

image.altText: A white police truck is parked on the side of the road next to a taped-off field

items.synopsis: Jerry Robertson has appeared in Alice Springs Local Court after being charged with murder, breaching a domestic violence order and being armed with an offensive weapon at night.

title.children: Man charged with murdering his partner at Alice Springs bush camp

image.altText: A picture of open palms of both hands with yellow sand covering them on a beach

items.synopsis: Traditional owners celebrate the federal government's decision to establish the Crocodile Islands archipelago off Arnhem Land as an Indigenous Protected Area.

title.children: 'We want it to stay as it is': Indigenous Protected Area declared in Crocodile Islands

image.altText: A large, double-span bridge curves across a blue-grey body of water in the daytime.

items.synopsis: Crimea's Russian-installed governor says an "emergency" situation had occurred near the 145th pillar of the bridge, which links the Crimean Peninsula to the Russian mainland.

title.children: Blasts reported on bridge between Russia and Crimea, authorities say child injured in 'emergency situation'

image.altText: A with a serious expression wears a dark tracksuit, a chain around his neck, and sunglasses on his head.

items.synopsis: A Gippsland man who broke into a family's home carrying an imitation firearm will be released from prison after a judge said he showed "immediate remorse".

title.children: Armed robber apologises, pays back money and asks for lift home after seeing victim at pokies

image.altText: A man in a suit standing in front of a purple screen

items.synopsis: Fortescue Metals hired lawyers to investigate the behaviour of its executive chairman Andrew Forrest after receiving an anonymous complaint, but made no adverse findings against the billionaire philanthropist.

title.children: Andrew Forrest cleared of wrongdoing after Fortescue investigation into claims of inappropriate behaviour

image.altText: A couple stand together by a railing on a boat and smile

items.synopsis: The criminal trial into the Whakaari White Island disaster has heard evidence from an Australian survivor who lost both his parents and his only sister in the 2019 eruption.

title.children: 'It still bothers me': Court hears of moment Whakaari survivor was separated from family

image.altText: Images of six people in a digital collage on shapes that appear to form buildings. There are two cranes on top of these shapes.

items.synopsis: For years, Dyldam's string of company collapses has anguished apartment buyers, angered subcontractors, and frustrated liquidators.

title.children: The family empire behind a succession of company collapses, defective buildings and unpaid tradies

image.altText: Flight crew load a stretcher into a helicopter on a hospital flight pad.

items.synopsis: Rangers say a woman has suffered bites to the lower half of her body after dingoes followed her into the water while she was running along a beach at K'gari (Fraser Island).

title.children: Jogger flown to hospital after being attacked by four dingoes on K'gari in 'very traumatic ordeal'

image.altText: A woman crouches next to a campfire on a beach at sunset

items.synopsis: Australians have a reputation for being a sociable bunch, but we're spending more time alone than ever before. Experts say social media, living alone and a fashion for being busy is driving the trend.

title.children: 'Being lonely is like being hungry or thirsty': Why aren't Australians socialising like they used to?

image.altText: Silhouette of an Australian solder in Afghanistan.

items.synopsis: Two years after the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide was formed, one of the commissioners tells the opening hearing in Adelaide that key themes to have emerged so far include a "terrible ADF culture" and "bullying, harassment, and abuses of power".

title.children: 'Terrible culture' and 'bullying' within ADF among key themes confronted by royal commission

image.altText: police some holding rifles and others crouching behind cars attend a siege situation in a town in new south wales

items.synopsis: Police believe the 29-year-old man died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound after they tried to negotiate with him from about midday on Sunday.

title.children: Man dies from gunshot wound after 21-hour siege with NSW police

image.altText: Firefighters with hoses spray water on a burning house

items.synopsis: A recently purchased luxury holiday home on South Australia's Fleurieu Peninsula has been destroyed in a fire overnight.

title.children: Luxury Fleurieu Peninsula holiday house destroyed by fire

image.altText: Spain's Carlos Alcaraz celebrates with the trophy after winning his final match against Serbia's Novak Djokovic.

items.synopsis: Carlos Alcaraz defeats Novak Djokovic to win Wimbledon in a five-set epic that saw a 26-minute service game, superb tennis and Djokovic destroying a racquet on the net post.

title.children: Carlos Alcaraz wins his first Wimbledon title, leaves Novak Djokovic fuming and snaps 45-match winning streak

image.altText: A black and white cut-out photo of Wendie Renard kicking a soccerball, against a pale orange background

items.synopsis: More than 700 of the world's best football players will take to stadium pitches all over Australia when FIFA 2023 kicks off this week. The ABC has crunched the data — these are the stars and breakthrough talents you should be looking out for.

title.children: You may not have heard of Wendie Renard, but the 189cm defender could turn out to be the star of the World Cup

image.altText: the PWC sign inside its lobby, with a woman in a red jacket walking by

items.synopsis: Until now, the big four accounting firms had built themselves an aura of credibility and trust in government and corporate Australia, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: How four companies infiltrated governments and took home $10 billion

image.altText: Flu vaccination

items.synopsis: Most of the children in hospital were diagnosed with influenza B and only one had been vaccinated.

title.children: Queenslanders to get free flu jabs with concerns about number of young people in hospital

image.altText: Long shot of an older indigenous man standing in tall grass near a statue.

items.synopsis: The Yindjibarndi Aboriginal Corporation has fought for years for compensation from iron ore mines in the Pilbara, but may soon be producing renewable energy to sell to those same companies.

title.children: Multi-billion-dollar renewables project earmarked for Yindjibarndi native title land

image.altText: Rescuers wade waist-deep in floodwaters in front of a submerged bus.

items.synopsis: Days of torrential rain leaves dozens dead and at least nine missing, many of whom were trapped in a flooded tunnel in the central city of Cheongju.

title.children: South Korean president orders all-out effort as flood death toll rises to 40

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: The ASX is following Wall Street's subdued lead from Friday with flat trade, while the Senate continues to probe the consulting industry. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: 'Bastardisation' of consulting partnerships 'warrants' royal commission, ASX trades flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After a tough year in 2021-22, when the typical balanced fund delivered a 3.4% loss, super returns bounced back in the financial year just ended. SuperRatings has released its list of the best performing funds, with the top 10 averaging 9.5% returns. This was the past year performance of those 10 funds, plus the average of the 50 balanced funds that SuperRatings looked at: ESSSuper Accum — Basic Growth	13.3% Vision SS — Balanced Growth	11.0% Brighter Super Accum — Balanced	10.6% UniSuper Accum — Balanced	10.3% Equip MyFuture — Balanced Growth	10.1% Australian Retirement Trust — Super Savings — Balanced	10.0% IOOF Employer Super Core — IOOF MultiSeries 70	9.8% Aware Super Future Saver — Balanced	9.7% Mercer Super Trust — Mercer Select Growth	9.6% HESTA — Balanced Growth	9.6% SR50 Balanced (60-76) Index	9.0% As for the long-term performers over the past decade: Hostplus — Balanced	8.0% AustralianSuper — Balanced	8.2% Australian Retirement Trust — Super Savings — Balanced	10.0% UniSuper — Balanced	10.3% Cbus — Growth (MySuper)	9.0% Vision Super — Balanced Growth	11.0% CareSuper — Balanced	9.1% HESTA — Balanced Growth	9.6% Aware Super Future Saver — Balanced	9.7% Spirit Super — Balanced (MySuper)	9.2% SR50 Balanced (60-76) Index	9.0% "We observed funds reviewing and writing down their unlisted asset valuations at the end of the financial year, contributing to the moderately weaker annual performance of funds with significant exposure to these assets in FY23," said SuperRatings executive director Kirby Rappell. "However, over the long term, they have added value to member outcomes, with many of the top performing options over 10 years having exposure to alternative assets. "Superannuation continues to deliver for members over the long term with annual returns of 7.1% since compulsory superannuation began in 1992."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rebounding share markets drive positive superannuation returns

children.content: After a tough year in 2021-22, when the typical balanced fund delivered a 3.4% loss, super returns bounced back in the financial year just ended.
SuperRatings has released its list of the best performing funds, with the top 10 averaging 9.5% returns.
This was the past year performance of those 10 funds, plus the average of the 50 balanced funds that SuperRatings looked at:
Australian Retirement Trust — Super Savings — Balanced	10.0%
IOOF Employer Super Core — IOOF MultiSeries 70	9.8%
Mercer Super Trust — Mercer Select Growth	9.6%
As for the long-term performers over the past decade:
Australian Retirement Trust — Super Savings — Balanced	10.0%

"We observed funds reviewing and writing down their unlisted asset valuations at the end of the financial year, contributing to the moderately weaker annual performance of funds with significant exposure to these assets in FY23," said SuperRatings executive director Kirby Rappell.
"However, over the long term, they have added value to member outcomes, with many of the top performing options over 10 years having exposure to alternative assets.
"Superannuation continues to deliver for members over the long term with annual returns of 7.1% since compulsory superannuation began in 1992."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We got the latest second quarter gross domestic product (GDP) data out from China today. While 6.3% year-on-year growth is nothing to sneeze at, and a big improvement from the first quarter's 4.5%, it was still way off what analysts were hoping to see. The median forecast was for 7.3% growth. ANZ's Betty Wang says more detail from the GDP data will be released tomorrow, but other information highlights China's economic problems. "More business weakness is seen in the private sector compared with their state-owned counterparts. FAI (fixed-asset investment) growth of the private sector contracted by 0.2% y/y YTD in June, the second month of decline, versus 8.1% growth of the state-owned sector," she noted. Fixed-asset investment not only drives growth now, but lays the foundations for future growth. "The surveyed youth unemployment rate rose to 21.3% in June for the16-24 years age group, advancing for the sixth consecutive month since January," Ms Wang observed. Amid a sluggish labour market and falling property prices, Chinese residents are saving even more than usual. "Household deposits grew 17-18% y/y in H1, the highest level in the past decade. The outstanding amount is equivalent to more than 30 months of retail sales," Ms Wang added. Despite a seemingly strong 6.3% headline growth rate, few indicators are pointing to a Chinese economy roaring back into life post-COVID.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China's economic rebound disappoints again

children.content: We got the latest second quarter
is nothing to sneeze at, and a big improvement from the first quarter's 4.5%, it was still way off what analysts were hoping to see.
says more detail from the GDP data will be released tomorrow, but other information highlights China's economic problems.

"More business weakness is seen in the private sector compared with their state-owned counterparts. FAI (fixed-asset investment) growth of the private sector contracted by 0.2% y/y YTD in June, the second month of decline, versus 8.1% growth of the state-owned sector," she noted.
Fixed-asset investment not only drives growth now, but lays the foundations for future growth.
"The surveyed youth unemployment rate rose to 21.3% in June for the16-24 years age group, advancing for the sixth consecutive month since January," Ms Wang observed.
Amid a sluggish labour market and falling property prices, Chinese residents are saving even more than usual.
"Household deposits grew 17-18% y/y in H1, the highest level in the past decade. The outstanding amount is equivalent to more than 30 months of retail sales," Ms Wang added.
Despite a seemingly strong 6.3% headline growth rate, few indicators are pointing to a Chinese economy roaring back into life post-COVID.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fortescue Metals engaged a law firm to investigate the behaviour of executive chairman Andrew Forrest after receiving an anonymous letter, but cleared him of any wrongdoing. Seyfarth Shaw LLP concluded that none of the matters in the letter were substantiated and there were no adverse findings, a Fortescue Metals spokesman said in a statement. The statement did not disclose the nature of the allegations and did not say when the internal probe took place. The Australian Financial Review reported on Sunday the investigation involved whether Mr Forrest had been in a relationship with a Fortescue employee. Read more below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Andrew Forrest cleared of wrongdoing after Fortescue review

featuredLink.title: Andrew Forrest cleared of wrongdoing after Fortescue investigation into claims of inappropriate behaviour

children.content: Fortescue Metals engaged a law firm to investigate the behaviour of executive chairman Andrew Forrest after receiving an anonymous letter, but cleared him of any wrongdoing.
Seyfarth Shaw LLP concluded that none of the matters in the letter were substantiated and there were no adverse findings, a Fortescue Metals spokesman said in a statement.
The statement did not disclose the nature of the allegations
and did not say when the internal probe took place.
The Australian Financial Review reported on Sunday the investigation involved whether Mr Forrest had been in a relationship with a Fortescue employee.

items.synopsis: Alternative protein producers in Australia are navigating a period of reset following a dramatic year of stock market price falls for major meat substitute companies.

title.children: Plant-based food industry makes leap forward as scientists discover missing 'fatty' meat flavour

items.synopsis: Tasmania is the first state to officially recognise those who identify as asexual, adding the A to the LGBTIQ+ initialism on all government documents.

title.children: First Australian state officially adds 'A' to recognised LGBTIQ+ term

title.children: Why have these tiny, colourful Gouldian finches vanished from a Kimberley refuge?

title.children: From pink cocaine to dangerous opioids — what Australia's first drug-checking site found in its inaugural year

title.children: Horse owners urged to be vigilant after 10 animals suddenly die

items.synopsis: The case for and against David Warner retaining his opener spot as Australia faces tough selection choices ahead of the fourth Ashes Test at Old Trafford.

title.children: David Warner poses a problem at the top of the batting order, but what other options are there?
